topics.heading: Simple, Complex, Compound and Complex Compound Sentence

questions.question:
Select the option that combines the ideas into one independent clause without adding another independent or dependent clause:
'The sun rose. The sky turned pink.'
options: The sun rose because the sky turned pink.
The sky turned pink because the sun rose.
The sky turned pink as the sun rose.
The sun rose, turning the sky pink.
questions.explanation: Option d) is correct because 'turning the sky pink' is a participial phrase modifying 'The sun rose,' creating one independent clause. Other options form compound or complex sentences.

questions.question:
Select the option that combines the ideas into one independent clause:
'The rain stopped. The clouds cleared.'
options: The rain stopped, and the clouds cleared.
The clouds cleared as the rain stopped.
The rain stopped, clearing the clouds.
The rain stopped, which made the clouds clear.
questions.explanation: Option c) is correct because 'clearing the clouds' is a participial phrase modifying 'The rain stopped,' creating a simple sentence.

questions.question:
Select the option that combines the ideas into one independent clause:
'The boy ran. He shouted with excitement.'
options: The boy ran, and he shouted with excitement.
The boy ran while shouting with excitement.
The boy ran, shouting with excitement.
The boy shouted with excitement because he ran.
questions.explanation: Option c) is correct because 'shouting with excitement' is a participial phrase modifying 'The boy ran,' forming a simple sentence.

questions.question:
Select the option that joins two independent clauses with a coordinating conjunction, maintaining their status as independent clauses:
'The lights went out. We lit candles.'
options: The lights went out because we lit candles.
The lights went out, so we lit candles.
We lit candles after the lights went out.
Although the lights went out, we lit candles.
questions.explanation: Option b) is correct because it joins two independent clauses with 'so,' forming a compound sentence.

questions.question:
Select the option that joins two independent clauses with a coordinating conjunction:
'She practiced every day. She became a great musician.'
options: She practiced every day, and she became a great musician.
She practiced every day when she became a great musician.
She became a great musician because she practiced every day.
She practiced every day as she became a great musician.
questions.explanation: Option a) is correct because it joins two independent clauses with 'and,' forming a compound sentence.

questions.question:
Select the option that joins two independent clauses with a coordinating conjunction:
'It was raining. We decided to stay indoors.'
options: We decided to stay indoors although it was raining.
It was raining, so we decided to stay indoors.
It was raining because we decided to stay indoors.
We decided to stay indoors as it was raining.
questions.explanation: Option b) is a compound sentence because it connects two independent clauses ('It was raining' and 'We decided to stay indoors') using the coordinating conjunction 'so,' indicating a cause-and-effect relationship.

questions.question:
Select the option that creates a complex sentence by combining the clauses:
'I didn’t go to the party. I wasn’t feeling well.'
options: I didn’t go to the party because I wasn’t feeling well.
I didn’t go to the party, and I wasn’t feeling well.
I wasn’t feeling well, so I didn’t go to the party.
I didn’t go to the party; I wasn’t feeling well.
questions.explanation: Option a) is a complex sentence because 'because I wasn’t feeling well' is a dependent clause explaining the reason for the independent clause 'I didn’t go to the party.'

questions.question:
Select the option that creates a complex sentence by combining the clauses:
'She read the book. She wrote a review.'
options: After she read the book, she wrote a review.
She read the book, and she wrote a review.
She wrote a review because she read the book.
She wrote a review, and then she read the book.
questions.explanation: Option a) is a complex sentence because 'After she read the book' is a dependent clause explaining when the action of the independent clause 'she wrote a review' occurred.

questions.question:
Select the option that creates a complex sentence by combining the clauses:
'I missed the bus. I woke up late.'
options: I missed the bus because I woke up late.
I missed the bus, and I woke up late.
I woke up late, so I missed the bus.
I missed the bus after I woke up late.
questions.explanation: Option a) forms a complex sentence with the dependent clause 'because I woke up late' providing the reason for the independent clause 'I missed the bus.'

questions.question:
Complete the sentence:
'He refused to eat _______ he was not hungry.'
options: because
although
but
and
questions.explanation: Option a) 'because' correctly introduces the reason he refused to eat, forming a complex sentence.

questions.question:
Fill in the blank:
'Hardly had he finished the report _______ his supervisor asked for another one.'
options: than
when
since
as soon as
questions.explanation: Option b) 'when' completes the sentence with the structure 'Hardly... when,' indicating that the supervisor’s request happened immediately after the report was finished.

questions.question: She will keep practicing piano _______ she becomes an expert.
options: until
since
unless
as though
questions.explanation: Option a) 'until' correctly expresses that her practice will continue up to the point when she becomes an expert.

questions.question:
Rearrange the following words to form a complex-compound sentence:
'he / went / the doctor / he / since / felt / ill / and / took / medicine'
options: Since he felt ill, he went to the doctor and took medicine.
He felt ill, so he went to the doctor and took medicine.
He went to the doctor and took medicine because he felt ill.
After feeling ill, he went to the doctor and took medicine.
questions.explanation: Option a) represents a complex-compound sentence with a dependent clause ('Since he felt ill') and two independent clauses ('he went to the doctor' and 'he took medicine') joined by 'and.'

questions.question:
Rearrange the following words to form a simple sentence:
'drinks / coffee / she / every / morning'
options: She drinks coffee every morning.
She drinks coffee every morning, and she also has breakfast.
Because she likes coffee, she drinks it every morning.
She drinks coffee after every morning run.
questions.explanation: Option a) represents a simple sentence with a subject ('she'), verb ('drinks'), and an object ('coffee').

questions.question:
Rewrite the following simple sentence as a compound sentence:
'She studies every night.'
options: She studies every night, and she works on weekends.
Because she studies every night, she passes her exams.
After she studies, she takes a break.
She studies every night because she wants to succeed.
questions.explanation: Option a) represents a compound sentence, as it joins two independent clauses with 'and.'

questions.question:
Rewrite the following simple sentence as a compound sentence:
'The team worked late into the night.'
options: The team worked late into the night, but they were exhausted.
The team worked late into the night so that they could win.
After the team worked late into the night, they celebrated.
Although the team worked late into the night, they were focused.
questions.explanation: Option a) represents a compound sentence joining two independent clauses with 'but.'

questions.question:
Identify the type of sentence:
'While I was studying, the power went out, but I continued to work.'
options: Simple
Compound
Complex
Complex-compound
questions.explanation: Option d) represents a complex-compound sentence with multiple independent clauses ('the power went out' and 'I continued to work') and one dependent clause ('While I was studying').

questions.question:
Identify the type of sentence:
'If it rains tomorrow, we will cancel the picnic, and we will move it to next week.'
options: Simple
Compound
Complex
Complex-compound
questions.explanation: Option d) represents a complex-compound sentence that includes a dependent clause ('If it rains tomorrow') and two independent clauses ('we will cancel the picnic' and 'we will move it to next week').

questions.question:
Rewrite the following simple sentence as a compound sentence:
'The city has a vibrant nightlife.'
options: The city has a vibrant nightlife, so many tourists visit.
Because the city has a vibrant nightlife, it attracts visitors.
The city has a vibrant nightlife, and it hosts many events.
After the city has a vibrant nightlife, it becomes lively.
questions.explanation: Option c) represents a compound sentence connecting two independent clauses with 'and.'

questions.question:
Rewrite the following simple sentence as a compound sentence:
'She completed her thesis.'
options: She completed her thesis, and she defended it successfully.
Since she completed her thesis, she felt accomplished.
After she completed her thesis, she took a break.
She completed her thesis because she worked hard.
questions.explanation: Option a) represents a compound sentence that combines two independent clauses with 'and.'
